For example: "General Support 2020" or "Happy Readers of Cleveland." Out of School Time Programming in Cleveland Ohio. Printed On: 27 March 2023 Education for 2022 2 Liz Lazar Boys and Girls Clubs of Northeast Ohio Mission Impact* Please tell us in 1500 characters (approx 250 words) how this request impacts our mission of : Helping underserved individuals move toward self-sufficiency. BGCNEO provides youth with safe, welcoming spaces to participate in unique programs and once-in-alifetime experiences. Members form strong relationships, eat nutritious meals, and build confidence and character. Clubs offer opportunities that many youth may otherwise never have, helping bridge the gap for kids experiencing poverty and disinvestment in their schools and communities. Through age-appropriate curriculum, youth work to build progressive pathways towards high school graduation and beyond. All BGCNEO programs fall under the pillars of academics, health & wellness, and character & leadership, but the real fun lies in the details. Members participate in activities ranging from sports leagues to musical instruments, to practicing yoga and meditation, creating podcasts, skiing, and snowboarding, cultivating a garden, cooking, working as Junior Staff, participating in career cohorts with the Cleveland Guardians or Hyland Software, or traveling on an out of state college exposure trip. These are just a small assortment of the many opportunities that await each youth that walks through the doors of a BGCNEO Club. Regardless of challenging life circumstances, regularly attending youth demonstrate improved academic performance, strong peer & mentor relationships, and a substantial awareness of the impact of good decision-making. They are curious, talented, ambitious, and kind, and work hard daily to overcome limitations and strive to reach their greatest potential. Liz Lazar Boys and Girls Clubs of Northeast Ohio
 Mission Impact* 
 Please tell us in 1500 characters (approx 250 words) how this request impacts our mission of : Helping underserved individuals move toward self-sufficiency.
 BGCNEO provides youth with safe, welcoming spaces to participate in unique programs and once-in-alifetime experiences. Members form strong relationships, eat nutritious meals, and build confidence and
 character. Clubs offer opportunities that many youth may otherwise never have, helping bridge the gap for
 kids experiencing poverty and disinvestment in their schools and communities. Through age-appropriate
 curriculum, youth work to build progressive pathways towards high school graduation and beyond. All
 BGCNEO programs fall under the pillars of academics, health & wellness, and character & leadership, but the
 real fun lies in the details. Members participate in activities ranging from sports leagues to musical
 instruments, to practicing yoga and meditation, creating podcasts, skiing, and snowboarding, cultivating a
 garden, cooking, working as Junior Staff, participating in career cohorts with the Cleveland Guardians or
 Hyland Software, or traveling on an out of state college exposure trip. These are just a small assortment of
 the many opportunities that await each youth that walks through the doors of a BGCNEO Club. Regardless of
 challenging life circumstances, regularly attending youth demonstrate improved academic performance,
 strong peer & mentor relationships, and a substantial awareness of the impact of good decision-making. They
 are curious, talented, ambitious, and kind, and work hard daily to overcome limitations and strive to reach
 their greatest potential. 
 Project Description* 
 For General Operating Support you may give more detail or simply enter GOS (General Operating Support)
 Funding from The Reinberger Foundation would support BGCNEO Cleveland’s general operations and
 programs, aimed at improving academic performance, health and well-being, and character and leadership
 development in youth ages 6-18.

 There are other times she would rather forget. 
 In sixth grade, she missed four months of school following reconstructive surgery to straighten her

 Joining the Boys & Girls Club was a turning point. “I absolutely fell in love with the Club,” she says. 
 “It is safe, homey and relaxing. If I needed someone, they were there. They make you a better person.”

 LOI Form 
 Organization Information 
 Mission Statement* 
 Click on the Guidestar Logo to pull in your mission statement from your Guidestar profile. You can edit this as
 needed—please review it for accuracy before submitting you LOI. 
 If you don't have a Guidestar profile, enter your mission statement. 
 The mission of the Boys & Girls Clubs of Northeast Ohio (BGCNEO) is to inspire and enable all young people to
 reach their full potential as productive, responsible and caring citizens.
 Do you use a Fiscal Sponsor?* 
 Geography 
 What geographic area does this request serve?* 
 Northeast Ohio

 Project Name* 
 Please keep the title short (100 characters), no need to repeat the Organization's name in the title.
 For example: "General Support 2020" or "Happy Readers of Cleveland." 
 Out of School Time Programming in Cleveland Ohio. 
 Printed On: 27 March 2023 Education for 2022 2

Liz Lazar Boys and Girls Clubs of Northeast Ohio
 Mission Impact* 
 Please tell us in 1500 characters (approx 250 words) how this request impacts our mission of : Helping underserved individuals move toward self-sufficiency.
 BGCNEO provides youth with safe, welcoming spaces to participate in unique programs and once-in-alifetime experiences. Members form strong relationships, eat nutritious meals, and build confidence and
 character. Clubs offer opportunities that many youth may otherwise never have, helping bridge the gap for
 kids experiencing poverty and disinvestment in their schools and communities. Through age-appropriate
 curriculum, youth work to build progressive pathways towards high school graduation and beyond. All
 BGCNEO programs fall under the pillars of academics, health & wellness, and character & leadership, but the
 real fun lies in the details. Members participate in activities ranging from sports leagues to musical
 instruments, to practicing yoga and meditation, creating podcasts, skiing, and snowboarding, cultivating a
 garden, cooking, working as Junior Staff, participating in career cohorts with the Cleveland Guardians or
 Hyland Software, or traveling on an out of state college exposure trip. These are just a small assortment of
 the many opportunities that await each youth that walks through the doors of a BGCNEO Club. Regardless of
 challenging life circumstances, regularly attending youth demonstrate improved academic performance,
 strong peer & mentor relationships, and a substantial awareness of the impact of good decision-making. They
 are curious, talented, ambitious, and kind, and work hard daily to overcome limitations and strive to reach
 their greatest potential. 
 Project Description* 
 For General Operating Support you may give more detail or simply enter GOS (General Operating Support)
 Funding from The Reinberger Foundation would support BGCNEO Cleveland’s general operations and
 programs, aimed at improving academic performance, health and well-being, and character and leadership
 development in youth ages 6-18.

Your generosity helped make the year a success 
 At the start of 2020, we were ready for takeoff. 
 We were a newly merged organization with new leadership and plans to 
 serve more kids in more places. It didn’t happen. I don’t have to tell you 
 OF NORTHEAST OHIO 
 why. All our worlds were turned upside down. 
 OUR MISSION 
 Here’s what did happen. 
 To provide and support the safe, 
 fun places and life-changing 
 You came through for our kids when they needed it most. You supported 
 opportunities during Boys & Girls Clubs of Northeast Ohio in a tumultuous time, one that 
 after-school hours that all prompted us to change our traditional operating model in order to serve 
 young people deserve in order young people who were learning virtually. Our kids delivered as well,

 never see again. 
 thrive in adulthood. 
 That’s why ‘Stepping Up’ is the title of this year’s annual report. When the 
 pandemic temporarily closed our doors, you helped reopen them with your 
 generosity. When our young people – many caught in the digital divide – 
 learned they could go to our Clubs during the school day to get in-person 
 OF NORTHEAST OHIO 
 and tech help, they took advantage of the opportunity. 
 I hope you will read the inspiring stories in this publication. Nathaniel’s 
 determination following the loss of his mom. Jayde’s amazing triumph 
 at the state swimming meet. Floyd’s work to improve his grades. 
 And Abrianna becoming Ohio Boys & Girls Clubs Youth of the Year. 
 We cannot thank you enough for all you have done for our kids. 
 You are making a difference. Please accept our enduring gratitude. 
 Jeff Scott

 Ohio s Youth of the Year 
 The pandemic challenged even the best of students. Just ask Abrianna Johnson.
 Abrianna, 18, an honor student at Akron’s Archbishop Hoban High School and the
 reigning Ohio Boys & Girls Clubs Youth of the Year, did not take to online learning

 She says the pandemic taught her a few things. 
 “I felt it helped me learn about myself,” she says. “I’m not a very social person, but
 I found out I really missed being around my friends on the track team and at the
 Club. It felt so good to see them again.” 
 Abrianna captured the Boys & Girls Clubs state Youth of the Year title in early 2021.
 She says winning the honor has been a goal since her freshman year. “I feel so good
 and so blessed,” she says. 
 Abrianna, who lives in Akron, says she will always treasure this time in her life.

 “Even though time goes on and I will get older, I have every intention of giving back
 BGCNEO’s Youth of the Year 
 to my Club and my community.”

He survives and thrives after 
 ‘ ’ 
 the hardest year of my life ’ 
 First, his school closed. Two months later, his mom died unexpectedly. He then 
 spent a grief-filled summer living “from couch to couch” as the family struggled 
 to make ends meet. Distracted and distraught, he did not embrace the online 
 learning that greeted him in the fall. 
 Nathaniel Rush thought about giving up. 
 But he didn’t. Lifted up by friends, family members and his Boys & Girls Club 
 director, Joseph Greathouse, Nathaniel, 18, went to work. He studied harder in 
 school, took advice more seriously and used daily pickup basketball games at his 
 Cleveland Club as “my relief from stress.” 
 Today, Nathaniel is a Cleveland Central Catholic High School graduate and has 
 “I feel like the 
 been accepted into Cleveland State University, where he plans to pursue a liberal 
 arts degree with a focus on history. 
 hardest year of my 
 “I feel like the hardest year of my life was also the most motivating year of my 
 life,” he says. “I learned so much. The Club pushes everyone to be better, and 
 life was also the most 
 that includes me. Everybody wants to be successful, but not everyone is willing 
 to put in the work to be successful.” 
 motivating year

 with help from Club school 
 Floyd, 13, was struggling and needed help. 
 “I feel like 
 He had a lot of trouble learning virtually. With his Lorain school temporarily closed

 I’ve become 
 He was falling behind.

 a better 
 Campus, became a ClubSmart Learning Center, where kids like him could receive

 person.” 
 High School, opened its doors two days a week. 
 “My grades,” Floyd says with a smile, “went up like crazy.” 
 The double dose of Club help and the return of in-school classes were a relief to
 Floyd and his aunt, with whom he lives. She is a former nurse who can no longer
 work due to a disability. 
 When he first joined the Boys & Girls Club, Floyd was, by all accounts, an angry
 kid. Staff members showed him techniques by which he could control his anger
 and have more fun. Today, he is a walking, talking advertisement for the Club and
 its ability to transform young lives. 
 “I feel like I’ve become a better person,” Floyd says. “I rarely get mad, and I am a
 lot happier. There is a lot to do. I really like the staff members and I get to hang out

The will to succeed drives Sandusky teen’ 
 Clustered around several computer screens, 15 teens watched, yelled and gestured excitedly. 
 The ruckus lasted only a half-minute or so, but Sandusky Teen Center Coordinator Allysa Powell 
 remembers it well. “There was,” she says, “a whole lot of screaming going on.” 
 The kids weren’t playing a game or watching a YouTube video. 
 They were pulling for one of their own.

 Jayde, 15, a three-year Club member, was competing in the paralympic 50-meter freestyle event at

 but I like who 
 Jayde, who also finished fourth in the 100-meter backstroke, started swimming at 7, when her 
 physical therapist put her in a pool. She loved it. “I will never forget that day,” she says. 
 I’ve become.” 
 There are other times she would rather forget. 
 In sixth grade, she missed four months of school following reconstructive surgery to straighten her 
 right foot. “I knew virtual (learning) before there was virtual,” she jokes. And she often found herself 
 getting picked on when she first moved to Sandusky from Bellevue. 
 Joining the Boys & Girls Club was a turning point. “I absolutely fell in love with the Club,” she says. 
 “It is safe, homey and relaxing. If I needed someone, they were there. They make you a better person.” 
 Today, a confident, smiling Jayde is an honor student with goals – and a lot of friends cheering her on.
